text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with okay that's right i generally
don't do videos and recipes that are
this trendy but in this case i'm going
to make an exception and that's because
there's a bunch of pull cable spots that
have sprung up in the neighborhood and
i'm watching my friends line up to pay
like $15 for what is essentially a few
cubes of raw tuna tossed in soy sauce
and of course there is a little more to
it than that but not much more so the
point of this video is to make sure
everyone that enjoys poke a is aware of
just how easy this is to make at home
and to get started we'll go ahead and
put together the only thing we need
besides the raw fish and that's going to
be our marinade which starts with some
soy sauce and no not low-sodium we're
going to need all the sodium we can get
here so I'm using regular real premium
soy sauce okay this stuff makes up the
majority of the marinade so you do want
to use something nice and then to that
we will add a couple tablespoons of
sesame oil which hopefully is relatively
fresh and you store it in the fridge
because that stuff can go rancid so if
you've had a bottle in the pantry
since Clooney was on television you may
want to toss that and get a new one and
then we're also going to do a little bit
of fresh ginger
I just grate that using the microplane
so we'll do a little fresh ginger
followed by some sliced green onion and
by the way if you have access to those
sweet Maui onions some of those thinly
sliced in this is very nice
and then I do like to add a little bit
of heat to this which we can do in a lot
of different ways this time I'm going to
use some Aleppo pepper which is pretty
and has no seeds Plus this proves I
don't put cayenne in every recipe so
we'll do a little heat which means we
also need a little bit of sweet which
I'll add in the form of some chopped up
macadamia nuts and while these aren't
traditional some Hawaii and not I forgot
the name of and then we can't get is so
we'll use this instead mostly so I can
eat the rest of the can and then we'll
also throw in a little bit of salt
preferably Hawaiian but if you don't
have that and you probably don't a
little bit of kosher spine and then last
but not least we'll toss in some weed
no not like Maui Wowi as in seaweed so I
have some dried seaweed which i believe
is called wacom a release that's what's
on the label and I know it looks black
but it's actually a really dark green so
what we'll do is we'll crumble in a
little bit of that which is not only
going to add another salty element but
also is going to add a very
steam flavor and one very reminiscent of
the sea and then once that's all
together we'll just take a whisk and
give it a quick mix and that is it for
our marinade and I should mention a lot
of people will just cut up their tuna
and just add all this stuff right into
the bowl but I really do prefer to mix
this up first that way you can sit with
all those ingredients kind of mingling
together while we cut our fish so we'll
go ahead and combine those ingredients
and simply set that aside while we prep
our tuna and for this we're going to
want to use a pound of the freshest tuna
you can find so if you only remember one
thing from this video let it be this
unless you can find very high-quality
sushi-grade tuna don't make this this
really only works with beautiful
impeccably fresh fish so what I have
here is a couple beautiful ahi tuna
steaks and what we'll do to prep this
stuff is basically cube it up and to his
even pieces as possible so what I like
to do is make some nice thick slices
across like this and then once I have
those in slices what I'll do is cut
those in half to make thick strips and
then we'll simply turn those and cut
them across the other way to make nice
neat hopefully evenly sized cubes and I
generally shoot for something that's
between a 1/2 inch and an inch but the
exact size is not the most important
thing that you pick a size and stick
with it is and why that's important so
this all marinates at the same rate oh
by the way if you're admiring that knife
and you want to know the brand so you
can get one sorry but you can't that was
Michelle's great-grandfather's so I have
no idea where it came from although I
tell people he won it in a poker game on
the Barbary Coast but anyway we're going
to go ahead and cube up our tuna at
which point we can go ahead and transfer
that into a mixing bowl and we will pour
over our marinade and we'll take a
spatula mix that very thoroughly and
while I'm mixing this together let me
explain the three approaches to serving
this ok the first would be to just toss
this and serve it immediately or what
we're going to do will mix this wrap it
up and let it sit in the fridge for an
hour - that seems to be the most popular
approach or third some people wrap this
up and they leave in the fridge
overnight or even up to two days which
personally I think is crazy I mean I
want poke a now but how the heck am I
going to know if I want to two days from
now a lot of things can happen in a
couple days so exactly how long you
decide to marinate this is going to be
up to you you are after all the boss so
making sure your PO K is okay but as I
mentioned
to go with the most popular approach
which would be to mix rap and pop this
in the fridge for a couple hours at
which point if everything's gone
according to plan
it should look something like this and
basically what's happened here is that
salt from the soy sauce is sort of cured
those pieces of tuna which is why they
have that gorgeous shimmery and sort of
translucent look to them and once we've
given that a mix with a spatula we're
basically ready to serve except of
course we have to taste for seasoning
and make sure it doesn't need any more
salt or heat or possibly acid because
I'm sure a few of you were wondering
doesn't this need a little acidity well
that depends on who you ask
I do enjoy a little bit of rice vinegar
and or lemon juice when I eat this but I
never include those ingredients in the
marinade because I really think it
affects the appearance adversely alright
we're not doing a ceviche here so I will
expand on this point in the blog post
but to summarize if you do want to
include some rice vinegar or lemon juice
or lime juice or whatever apply that
right before you're going to eat but
anyway assume in our pokey is seasoned
correctly we will go ahead and serve
that up and my favorite way to do one of
these bowls would be on top of some
sushi rice along with some kind of cold
seasonal vegetables so today I had some
beautiful heirloom cherry tomatoes which
I turned into a salad with a few soy
beans so I'll scatter some of that
around other popular choices would be
some thinly sliced onions or maybe some
cucumber or sweet pepper and or some
fresh herbs like cilantro so really this
is the kind of thing you should make
different every time based on what's in
season and whichever round and once our
veggies are down we'll go ahead and top
our sushi rice with our PO K and while I
do enjoyed on the sushi rice you can
also serve this on cold noodles as well
as the salad of course or what's also
really good is serve it as an appetizer
with fried wonton chips in fact now that
I think about that that might be my
favorite way but anyway we're going to
pile up that PO K and I'm gonna go ahead
and finish that up with a little more
green onion as well as some toasted
sesame seeds and that's it my poke a
bowl is done and looking very enticing I
mean if that doesn't look like the

and of course we have that little touch

I'm not saying it's better but I'm

is there's just so many different things
